revision.text:
{{Other uses|Philippine Spanish}} {{Spanish language}} [[Spanish language|Spanish]] was the [[official language]] of the [[Spanish East Indies|Philippines]] from the beginning of [[Spanish colonization of the Philippines|Spanish rule]] in the late 16th century, through the conclusion of the [[Spanish–American War]] in 1898. It remained, along with English, as co-official language until 1987. It was at first removed in 1973 by a constitutional change, but after a few months it was re-designated an official language by [[presidential decree]] and remained official until 1987, with the [[1987 Constitution|present Constitution]] re-designating it instead as an "optional and voluntary language". [[Philippine Spanish]] ({{lang-es|Español filipino, Castellano filipino}}) is a variant of standard [[Spanish language|Spanish]], spoken in the [[Philippines]] by a minority today, though it was quite widespread up to the early 20th century. The variant is very similar to [[Mexican Spanish]], because the Philippines was ruled from [[New Spain]] in present-day [[Mexico]], for over three centuries. During that period, there was much Spanish and Mexican emigration to the [[Spanish East Indies]]. It was the language of the [[Philippine Revolution]] and the country's first official language, as proclaimed in the [[Malolos Constitution]] of the [[First Philippine Republic]] in 1899. It was the language of commerce, law, politics and the arts during the colonial period and well into the 20th century. It was the main language of many classical writers and [[Ilustrados]] such as [[Jose Rizal]], [[Andres Bonifacio]], [[Antonio Luna]] and [[Marcelo del Pilar]], to name but a few. It is regulated by the [[Philippine Academy of the Spanish Language|Academia Filipina de la Lengua Española]], the main Spanish-language regulating body in the Philippines, and a member of the [[Asociación de Academias de la Lengua Española]], the entity which regulates the Spanish language worldwide. ==Background== ===Overview=== [[File:Flag of Spain (1785-1873 and 1875-1931).svg|thumb|Flag of Spain (1785–1873 and 1875–1931)]] {{main article|Philippine Spanish}} [[Philippine Spanish|Spanish]] was the language of government, education and trade throughout the three centuries of Spanish rule and continued to serve as a [[lingua franca]] until the first half of the 20th century.{{cite journal |last=Rodao |first=Florentino|year=1997|title=Spanish language in the Philippines : 1900–1940|journal=Philippine studies |volume=45 |series=12 |issue=1 |pages=94–107 |publisher=Ateneo de Manila University Press|location=Manila, Philippines |issn=0031-7837 |pmid= |pmc= |bibcode= |oclc=612174151 |id= |url=http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=2877788 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fcat.inist.fr%2F%3FaModele%3DafficheN%26cpsidt%3D2877788&date=2010-07-13 |archivedate=July 13, 2010 |accessdate=July 14, 2010 |ref=harv}} Spanish was the official language of the [[First Philippine Republic|Malolos Republic]], "for the time being", according to the [[Malolos Constitution]] of 1899.The [[Malolos Constitution]] was written in Spanish, and no official English translation was released. Article 93 read, "Artículo 93.° El empleo de las lenguas usadas en Filipinas es potestativo. No puede regularse sino por la ley y solamente para los actos de la autoridad pública y los asuntos judiciales. Para estos actos se usará por ahora la lengua castellana.";
A literal translation originally printed as exhibit IV, Volume I, ''Report of the Philippine Commission to the President'', January 31, 1900, Senate Document 188. Fifty-sixth Congress, first session.) read, "ART.93 The use of the languages spoken in the Philippines is optional. It can only be regulated by law, and solely as regards acts of public authority and judicial affairs. For these acts, the Spanish language shall be used for the time being.", {{Harvnb|Kalaw|1927||p=[http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer;cc=philamer;idno=afj2233.0001.001;frm=frameset;view=image;seq=463;page=root;size=s 443]}};
In 1972, the Philippine Government [[National Historical Institute]] (NHI) published {{Harvnb|Guevara|1972}}, which contained a somewhat different English translation in which Article 93 read, "Article 93. The use of languages spoken in the Philippines shall be optional. Their use cannot be regulated except by virtue of law, and solely for acts of public authority and in the courts. For these acts the Spanish language may be used in the meantime." {{Harvnb|Guevara|1972|p=[http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer;cc=philamer;idno=aab1246.0001.001;frm=frameset;view=image;seq=135;page=root;size=s 117]}};
Other translations also exist (e.g. {{Harvnb|Rodriguez|1997|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=l8alSTTrk48C&pg=PA130 130]}});
As of 2008, the NHI translation seems to predominate in publication, with some sources describing it as "official" or "approved": {{Harvnb|Rappa|Wee|2006|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=KXQTIl2eox4C&pg=PA67 67]}}; {{Harvnb|Woods|2005|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=2Z-n_kDTxf0C&pg=PA218 218]}}; {{Harvnb|Corpus Juris}}; {{Harvnb|LawPhil}}; (others). Spanish was also the official language of the [[Cantonal Republic of Negros]] of 1898 and the [[Republic of Zamboanga]] of 1899.{{cite web |url=http://www.zamboanga.com/history/republic_of_zamboanga.html |title=History of The Republic of Zamboanga (May 1899 – March 1903) |date=July 18, 2009 |publisher=Zamboanga ([http://www.zamboanga.com/ zamboanga.com]) |location=Zamboanga City, Philippines |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rfy8a79R?url=http://www.zamboanga.com/history/republic_of_zamboanga.html |archivedate=August 2, 2010 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} During the early part of the U.S. administration of the Philippine Islands, Spanish was widely spoken and relatively well maintained throughout the American colonial period.{{cite web |url=http://de.geocities.com/hispanofilipino/Articles/EstadisticasEng.html |title=Statistics: Spanish Language in the Philippines |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera|authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |publisher=Circulo Hispano-Filipino|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027104021/http://de.geocities.com/hispanofilipino/Articles/EstadisticasEng.html |archivedate=October 27, 2009 |accessdate=July 30, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/libradav_eng.html |title=The Librada Avelino-Gilbert Newton Encounter (Manila, 1913) |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |date=February 11, 2001 |publisher=Buscoenlaces |location=Spain |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQ7TiDi?url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/libradav_eng.html |archivedate=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Even so, Spanish was a language that bound leading men in the Philippines like Trinidad Hermenegildo Pardo de Tavera y Gorricho to [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Sergio Osmeña]] and his successor, President [[Manuel Roxas]]. As a senator, [[Manuel L. Quezon]] (later President), delivered a speech in the 1920s entitled "Message to My People" in English and in Spanish.{{cite web | title =Talumpati: Manuel L. Quezon | url=http://filipinolibrarian.blogspot.com/2006/08/talumpati-manuel-l-quezon.html | accessdate = 2010-06-26}} ===Official language=== {{main article|Philippine Academy of the Spanish Language}} Spanish remained an official language of government until a new constitution ratified on January 17, 1973 designated English and [[Filipino language|Pilipino]], spelled in that draft of the constitution with a "P" instead of the more modern "F", as official languages. Shortly thereafter, Presidential Proclamation No. 155 dated March 15, 1973 ordered that the Spanish language should continue to be recognized as an official language so long as government documents in that language remained untranslated. A later constitution ratified in 1987 designated [[Filipino language|Filipino]] and English as official languages.Article XIV, Section 3 of the [http://thecorpusjuris.com/laws/constitutions/item/1935-constitution.html 1935 Philippine Constitution] provided, "[...] Until otherwise provided by law, English and Spanish shall continue as official languages." The [http://thecorpusjuris.com/laws/constitutions/item/1943-constitution.html 1943 Philippine Constitution] (in effect during occupation by Japanese forces, and later repudiated) did not specify official languages. Article XV, Section 3(3) of the [http://thecorpusjuris.com/laws/constitutions/item/1973-constitution.html 1973 Philippine constitution] ratified on January 17, 1973 specified, "Until otherwise provided by law, English and Pilipino shall be the official languages. [http://www.chanrobles.com/presidentialdecrees/presidentialdecreeno155.html Presidential Decree No. 155] dated March 15, 1973 ordered, "[...] that the Spanish language shall continue to be recognized as an official language in the Philippines while important documents in government files are in the Spanish language and not translated into either English or Pilipino language." Article XIV Section 7 of the [http://www.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-article-xiv/ 1987 Philippine Constitution] specified, "For purposes of communication and instruction, the official languages of the Philippines are Filipino and, until otherwise provided by law, English." Also, under this Constitution, Spanish, together with Arabic, was designated an optional and voluntary language.'''Article XIV, Sec 7''': For purposes of communication and instruction, the official languages of the Philippines are Filipino and, until otherwise provided by law, English. The regional languages are the auxiliary official languages in the regions and shall serve as auxiliary media of instruction therein. '''Spanish''' and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis. ===Influence=== There are thousands of Spanish [[loanword]]s in 170 native [[Philippine languages]], and Spanish orthography has influenced the spelling system used for writing most of these languages.{{cite web |url=http://emanila.com/news/opinion/ggrivera_2001_04_10_opinion_tagalog.html |title=The evolution of the native Tagalog alphabet |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |date=April 10, 2001 |publisher=Emanila Community ([http://emanila.com/main/ emanila.com]) |at=Views & Reviews |location=Philippines |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rhjRPCO9?url=http://emanila.com/news/opinion/ggrivera_2001_04_10_opinion_tagalog.html |archivedate=August 3, 2010 |accessdate=August 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Demographics=== {{main article|Spanish Filipino}} According to the 1990 Philippine census, there were 2,660 native Spanish speakers in the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=PH|title=Languages of the Philippines|publisher=Ethnologue|accessdate=2009-08-22}} In 2013 there were also 3,325 Spanish residents.{{cite web|url=http://www.ine.es/jaxi/tabla.do?path=/t20/p85001/a2013/l0/&file=01001.px&type=pcaxis&L=0|title=Instituto Nacional de Estadística.|work=ine.es}} However, there are 439,000 Spanish speakers with native knowledge,{{Citation | url = http://www.realinstitutoelcano.org/wps/portal/rielcano/contenido?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/elcano/elcano_es/zonas_es/asia-pacifico/ari27-2009 | title = realinstitutoelcano.org | year = 2007}} which accounts for just 0.5% of the population (92,337,852 at the 2010 census).{{Citation | url = https://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/popproj_tab1r.html | publisher = Philippine Statistics Authority | title = Medium projection | year = 2010 | place = PH | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110811190921/http://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/popproj_tab1r.html | archivedate = 2011-08-11 | df = }} In 1998, there were 1.8 million Spanish speakers including those who spoke Spanish as a secondary language.{{Citation | first = Antonio | last = Quilis | title = La lengua española en Filipinas | year = 1996 | page = 54 and 55 | url = http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/servlet/SirveObras/01350553135573500088680/209438_0013.pd | publisher = Cervantes virtual | format = PDF}} ==History== ===Spanish colonial period=== [[File:Lopez de Legazpi.jpg|thumb|Statue of [[Miguel López de Legazpi]] just outside [[Fort San Pedro]], [[Cebu City]]]] {{See also|History of the Philippines|History of the Philippines (1521–1898)|Viceroyalty of New Spain|Spanish Empire|History of Spain}} Spanish was first introduced to the Philippines in 1565, when the conquistador, [[Miguel López de Legazpi]], founded the first Spanish settlement on the island of [[Cebu Island|Cebú]].{{Harvnb|Arcilla|1994|pp=7–11}} The Philippines, ruled first from [[Mexico City]] and later from [[Madrid]], was a [[Spanish Empire|Spanish territory]] for 333 years (1565–1898).{{Harvnb|Agoncillo|1990|pp=80, 212}} Schooling was a priority, however. The [[Augustinians]] opened a school immediately upon arriving in Cebú in 1565; the [[Franciscan]]s followed suit when they arrived in 1577, as did the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]] when they arrived in 1587. Besides religious instruction, these schools taught how to read and write and imparted industrial and agricultural techniques.{{Harvnb|Arcilla|1994|p=50}} Initially, the stance of the Roman Catholic Church and its [[missionary|missionaries]] was to preach to the natives in local languages, not in Spanish. The priests learned the native languages and sometimes employed indigenous peoples as [[translator]]s, creating a bilingual class known as Ladinos.{{cite web |url=http://www.sil.org/asia/philippines/ical/papers/Villareal-Hiligaynon_lang_desire.pdf |title=Language and Desire in Hiligaynon|work=[http://www.sil.org/asia/philippines/ical/papers.html Tenth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics] |first=Corazón |last=Villareal |date=January 17–20, 2006 |location=Puerto Princesa City, Palawan, Philippines |page=9 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070111134034/http://www.sil.org/asia/philippines/ical/papers/Villareal-Hiligaynon_lang_desire.pdf |archivedate=January 11, 2007 |accessdate=July 13, 2010 |quote=But the real authors were really the Ladinos, natives from the Philippine who were the informants, translators, or even better, consultants of the missionaries.}} Before the 19th century, the natives generally were not taught Spanish. However, there were notable bilingual individuals such as poet-translator [[Gaspar Aquino de Belén]]. Gaspar produced Christian devotional poetry written in the Roman script in the [[Tagalog language]]. [[Pasyon]] is a narrative of the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ begun by Gaspar Aquino de Belén, which has circulated in many versions. Later, the Spanish-Mexican ballads of chivalry, the [[corrido]], provided a model for secular literature. Verse narratives, or komedya, were performed in the [[Philippine languages|regional languages]] for the illiterate majority. In the early 17th century, a Tagalog-Chinese printer, Tomás Pinpin, set out to write a book in romanized phonetic script to teach the Tagalogs how to learn [[Names given to the Spanish language|Castilian]]. His book, published by the [[Dominican order|Dominican]] press where he worked, appeared in 1610, the same year as Blancas's ''Arte''. Unlike the missionary's grammar (which Pinpin had set in type), the Tagalog native's book dealt with the language of the dominant rather than the subordinate other. Pinpin's book was the first such work ever written and published by a Philippine native. As such, it is richly instructive for what it tells us about the interests that animated Tagalog translation and, by implication, Tagalog conversion in the early colonial period. [[Image:La Illustracion Filipina (1892).jpg|thumb|left|[[Juan Luna]] featured on the cover of a Spanish periodical]] By law, each town had to build two schools, one for boys and the other for girls, to teach the Spanish language and the [[catechism|Christian catechism]]. There were never enough trained teachers, however, and several provincial schools were mere sheds open to the rain. This discouraged the attendance at school and illiteracy was high in the provinces until the 19th century, when public education was introduced. The conditions were better in larger towns. To qualify as an independent civil town, a [[barrio]] or group of barrios had to have a priest's residence, a town hall, boys' and girls' schools; streets had to be straight and at right angles to one another so that the town could grow in size; the town had to be near a good water source and land for farming and grazing.{{Harvnb|Arcilla|1994|p=48}} Better school conditions in towns and cities led to more effective instruction in the Spanish language and in other subjects. Between 1600 and 1865, a number of colleges and universities were established, which graduated many important colonial officials and church prelates, bishops, and archbishops—several of whom served the churches in [[Hispanic America]]. The increased level of education eventually led to the rise of the [[Ilustrados]]. In 1846, French traveler [[Jean Baptiste Mallat]] was surprised at how advanced Philippine schools were. In 1865, the government inaugurated the Escuela Normal (''Normal School'', later [[Philippine Normal University]]), an institute to train future primary school teachers. At the same time, primary schooling was made compulsory for all children. In 1869, a new Spanish constitution brought to the Philippines universal suffrage and a free press.{{cite web | last = Beck | first = Sanderson | title =Summary and Evaluation | url=http://www.san.beck.org/21-Summary.html#a6 | accessdate = 2010-06-29}} ''El Boletín de Cebú'', the first Spanish newspaper in [[Cebu City]], was published in 1886.{{cite web | title =Newspaper | url=http://www.ngkhai.com/pointcebu/culture/newspaper.htm | accessdate = 2010-06-29}} In Manila, the Spanish language had been more or less widespread, to the point where it has been estimated at around 50% of the population knew Spanish in the late 19th century.{{Harvnb|Rodríguez-Ponga}} In his 1898 book "Yesterdays in the Philippines", covering a period beginning in 1893, the American [[Joseph Earle Stevens]], an American who resided in Manila from 1893 to 1894, wrote: {{cquote| Spanish, of course, is the court and commercial language and, except among the uneducated native who have a lingua of their own or among the few members of the [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] colony, it has a monopoly everywhere. No one can really get on without it, and even the Chinese come in with their peculiar [[pidgin]] variety.{{Harvnb|Stevens|1898|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=tp3eGtu54vgC&pg=PA11 11]}} }} Long contact between Spanish and the local languages, Chinese dialects, and later Japanese produced a series of pidgins, known as '''Bamboo Spanish''', and the Spanish-based creole [[Chavacano]]. At one point these were the language of a substantial proportion of the Philippine population.{{Harvnb|Penny|Penny|2002|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjcrhyQlFa0C&pg=PA29 29–30]}} Unsurprisingly, given that the Philippines was administrated for centuries from [[New Spain]] in present-day [[Mexico]], Philippine Spanish is broadly similar to [[Spanish language in the United States|American Spanish]], not only in vocabulary, but in pronunciation and grammar.{{Harvnb|Penny|Penny|2002|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjcrhyQlFa0C&pg=PA30 30]}} Although the Philippines were not as culturally hispanized as [[Hispanic America]], the Spanish language was the official language used by the civil and judicial administration, and was spoken by the majority of the population and understood by just everyone, especially after the passing of the Education Decree of 1863. By the end of the 19th century, Spanish was a strong second language among the upper classes of Philippine society, having been learned in childhood either directly from parents and grandparents or through tutoring by a local priest.{{cite book|author=Paul A. Kramer|title=Blood of Government: Race, Empire, the United States, and the Philippines: Race, Empire, the United States, and the Philippines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_Lx0KCui5IC|year=2006|publisher=Univ of North Carolina Press|isbn=978-0-8078-7717-3|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=K_Lx0KCui5IC&pg=PA61 61]}} By the time Spanish rule came to an end, Spanish was spoken as a second language by more than 60% of the population. ====Schools==== {{Main article|Philippines education during Spanish rule}} In the 16th and 17th centuries, the oldest educational institutions in the country were set up by Spanish religious orders. These schools and universities played a crucial role in the development of the Spanish language in the islands. Colegio de Manila in [[Intramuros]] was founded in 1590. The Colegio formally opened in 1595, and was one of the first schools in the Philippines.{{cite web | title =The First Hundred Years Of The Ateneo de Manila | url=http://www.ateneo.edu/index.php?p=348 | accessdate = 2010-06-29}} During the same year, the [[University of San Carlos]] in Cebú, was established as the Colegio de San Ildefonso by the Jesuits. In 1611, the [[University of Santo Tomás]], considered as the oldest existing university in Asia, was inaugurated in Manila by the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]]. In the 18th century, fluent male Spanish speakers in the Philippines were generally the graduates of these schools, as well as of the [[Colegio de San Juan de Letrán]], established in 1620. In 1706, a convent school for Philippine women known as Beaterios was established. It admitted both Spanish and native girls, and taught Religion, Reading, Writing and Arithmetic with Music and Embroidery. Female graduates from Beaterios were fluent in the language as well. In 1859, [[Ateneo de Manila University]] was established by the [[Jesuits]] as the Escuela Municipal. In 1863, Queen [[Isabel II of Spain]] decreed the establishment of a [[Public school (government funded)|public school]] system, following the requests of the Spanish authorities in the islands, who saw the need of teaching Spanish to the wider population. The primary instruction and the teaching of the Spanish language was compulsory. The Educational Decree provided for the establishment of at least one primary school for boys and girls in each town and governed by the municipal government. A Normal School for male teachers was established and was supervised by the Jesuits.{{cite web | title =Historical Perspective of the Philippine Educational System | url =http://www.deped.gov.ph/about_deped/history.asp | accessdate =2010-06-29 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110716160809/http://www.deped.gov.ph/about_deped/history.asp | archivedate =2011-07-16 | df = }}{{cite web | title = EDUCATION | url=http://countrystudies.us/philippines/53.htm | accessdate = 2010-06-29}} In 1866, the total population of the Philippines was only 4,411,261. The total public schools was 841 for boys and 833 for girls and the total number of children attending these schools was 135,098 boys and 95,260 girls. In 1892, the number of schools had increased to 2,137, 1,087 of which were for boys and 1,050 for girls. {{Cite book |url = http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer;cc=philamer;idno=anu3845.0001.001;frm=frameset;view=image;seq=43;size=100;page=root |title = Philippine Assembly, Third Legislature, Third Session, Document No.4042-A 87 Speeches of Honorable Manuel L. Quezon, Philippine resident commissioner, delivered in the House of Representatives of the United States during the discussion of Jones Bill, 26 September-14 October 1914 |first = Manuel Luis |last = Quezon |authorlink = Manuel L. Quezon |year = 1915 |page = 35 |chapter = Escuelas públicas durante el régimen español |trans-chapter = Public schools during the Spanish regime |chapterurl = http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer&cc=philamer&idno=anu3845.0001.001&frm=frameset&view=image&seq=42&size=100 |publisher = Bureau of Printing |location = Manila, Philippines |language = Spanish |trans-title = Asamblea Filipina, Tercera Legislatura, Tercer Período de Sesiones, Documento N.o 4042-A 87, Discursos del Hon. Manuel L. Quezon, comisionado residente de Filipinas, Pronunciados en la Cámara de representantes de los Estados Unidos con motivo de la discusión del Bill Jones, 26, septiembre-14, octubre, 1914 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5rJhcxXPH?url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer;cc=philamer;idno=anu3845.0001.001;frm=frameset;view=image;seq=43;size=100;page=root |archivedate = July 18, 2010 |accessdate = July 30, 2010 |ref = harv |postscript = |deadurl = yes |df = }} This measure was at the vanguard of contemporary Asian countries, and led to an important class of educated natives which sometimes followed their studies abroad, like national hero [[José Rizal]], who studied in Europe. This class of writers, poets and intellectuals is often referred to as [[Ilustrados]]. Ironically, it was during the initial years of American occupation in the early 20th century, that Spanish literature and press flourished. This was the result both of a majority of Spanish-speaking population, as well as the partial freedom of the press which the American rulers allowed. ====Filipino nationalism and 19th century revolutionary governments==== [[File:bandera 03.jpg|thumb|left|Early flag of the [[Philippine Revolutionary Army|Filipino revolutionaries]] ("Long live the Philippine Republic!"). The first two constitutions were written in Spanish.]] {{See also|Filipino nationalism|Philippine revolts against Spain|Propaganda Movement|La Solidaridad|Philippine Revolution}} Before the 19th century, [[Philippine revolts against Spain|Philippine revolts]] were small-scale and did not extend beyond linguistic boundaries. Thus, they were easily neutralized by Spanish forces.{{Harvnb|Guerrero|1987}} With the small period of the spread of Spanish through a free public school system (1863) and the rise of an educated class, nationalists from different parts of the archipelago were able to communicate in a [[lingua franca|common language]]. José Rizal's novels, [[Graciano López Jaena]]'s satirical articles, [[Marcelo H. del Pilar]]'s anti-clerical manifestos, the bi-weekly ''[[La Solidaridad]]'' which was published in Spain, and other materials in awakening nationalism were written in Spanish. The [[Philippine Revolution]] fought for reforms and later for independence from Spain. However, it did not oppose Spain's [[Spanish influence on Filipino culture|cultural legacy]] in the islands or the Spanish language.{{cite web |url=http://www.filipiniana.net/ArtifactView.do?artifactID=GVH200900002&query=la%20solidaridad&page=220# |title=La Solidaridad : Our purposes |first=Graciano |last=López Jaena |date=February 15, 1889 |publisher=La Solidaridad |location=Barcelona, Spain |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.filipiniana.net%2FArtifactView.do%3FartifactID%3DGVH200900002%26query%3Dla%2520solidaridad%26page%3D220%23&date=2010-07-13 |archivedate=July 13, 2010 |accessdate=July 14, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreeman.com/opinion/index.php?fullstory=1&issue=articles_20040627&id=19361 |title=The teaching of Spanish in the Philippines |first=Marcelo |last=del Pilar |date=February 15, 1889 |publisher=La Solidaridad |location=Barcelona, Spain|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820180839/http://www.thefreeman.com/opinion/index.php?fullstory=1&issue=articles_20040627&id=19361 |archivedate=August 20, 2006 |accessdate=July 14, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.filipiniana.net/ArtifactView.do?artifactID=GVH200900006&query=la%20solidaridad&page=62# |title=The aspirations of the Filipinos|first=Marcelo H.|last=del Pilar|date=April 25, 1889|publisher=La Solidaridad |location=Barcelona, Spain |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.filipiniana.net%2FArtifactView.do%3FartifactID%3DGVH200900006%26query%3Dla%2520solidaridad%26page%3D62&date=2010-07-13 |archivedate=July 13, 2010 |accessdate=July 14, 2010}} Even Graciano López Jaena's La Solidaridad article in 1889 praised the young women of [[Malolos]] who petitioned to [[Governor-General of the Philippines#Spanish Colonial Government (1764–1898)|Governor-General]] [[Valeriano Weyler, 1st Duke of Rubí|Valeriano Weyler]] to open a night school to teach the Spanish language.{{cite web |url=http://www.filipiniana.net/ArtifactView.do?artifactID=GVH201000017&query=La%20Solidaridad&page=234# |title=Congratulations to the young women of Malolos |first=Graciano |last=López Jaena |date=February 15, 1889 |publisher=La Solidaridad |location=Barcelona, Spain|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.filipiniana.net%2FArtifactView.do%3FartifactID%3DGVH201000017%26query%3DLa%2520Solidaridad%26page%3D234%23&date=2010-07-13 |archivedate= July 13, 2010 |accessdate=July 14, 2010}} In fact, the [[Revolutionary Government of the Philippines|Malolos Congress]] of 1899 chose Spanish as the official language. According to [[Horacio de la Costa]], nationalism would not have been possible without Spanish. by then increasingly aware of nationalistic ideas and independence movements in other countries. [[File:la-solidaridad2.jpg|thumb|[[Propaganda]] in Spanish]] Spanish was used by the first Filipino patriots like [[José Rizal]], [[Andrés Bonifacio]] and, to a lesser extent, [[Emilio Aguinaldo]]. The 1896 Biak-na-Bato Constitution and the 1898 Malolos Constitution were both written in Spanish. Neither specified a national language, but both recognised the continuing use of Spanish in Philippine life and legislation.{{cite journal|url=http://www.multilingual-matters.net/jmmd/019/0487/jmmd0190487.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114194404/http://www.multilingual-matters.net/jmmd/019/0487/jmmd0190487.pdf|archivedate=2009-01-14|format=PDF|last=Gonzalez|first=Andrew|journal=Journal of Multilingual and Multicultural Development|title=The Language Planning Situation in the Philippines|year=1998|volume=19|issue=5&6|page=513|ref=harv}} Aguinaldo was more comfortable speaking Tagalog.{{harvnb|Gonzalez|1998|p=521}} (Note 7) Spanish was used to write the [[Constitution of Biak-na-Bato]], [[Malolos Constitution]], the original [[national anthem]], ''Himno Nacional Filipino'', as well as nationalistic propaganda material and literature. The country's first two constitutions and historic novels were written in Spanish. While widely understood by the majority of the population, Spanish at this time was the unifying language since Tagalog was not as prominent or ubiquitous as it is today and each region had their own culture and language, and would rather speak in their local languages. Before the spread of Filipino nationalism, the natives of each region still thought of themselves as [[Ilocano people|Ilocano]], [[Cebuano people|Cebuano]], [[Bicolano people|Bicolano]], [[Waray people|Waray]], [[Tagalog people|Tagalog]] etc., and not as Filipinos. The term "Filipino" originally referred to the natives of the Philippines themselves. It was Pedro Chirino, a Spanish Jesuit, who first called the natives "Filipinos," in his book ''Relación de las Islas Filipinas'' (Rome, 1604). However, during their 333-year rule of the Philippines, the Spanish rulers preferred to call the natives ''Indios''.{{cite web|url=http://jonroyeca.blogspot.com/2012/11/sino-ang-mga-orihinal-na-pilipino.html|title=Jon E. Royeca|author=Jon E. Royeca|work=jonroyeca.blogspot.com}} Also during the colonial era, the Spaniards born in the Philippines, who were more known as insulares, criollos, or Creoles, were also called "Filipinos." [[Spain|Spanish-born]] Spaniards or mainland Spaniards residing in the Philippines were referred to as [[Peninsulares]]. Peoples born in Spanish America or in the North American continent of [[Viceroyalty of New Spain|New Spain]] who were residing in the Philippines were collectively referred to as [[Filipino mestizo#Colonial caste system|Americanos]]. The Catholic [[Austronesian peoples]] of the Philippines were referred to as [[Filipino mestizo#Colonial caste system|Indios]] and for those who were practicing the [[Islamic faith]], [[Moro people|Moros]]. The indigenous [[Aeta peoples|Aetas]] were referred to as [[Filipino mestizo#Colonial caste system|Negritos]]. [[Chinese Filipino|Chinese]] settlers were called [[Sangley]]es. Japanese settlers were called [[Japanese settlement in the Philippines|Japoneses]]. Those of mixed ancestry were referred to as [[Filipino mestizo#Colonial caste system|Mestizos]] or [[Tornatrás]]. In the 1800s, the term "Filipino" gradually became synonymous to anyone born in the Philippines regardless of ethnicity through the effort of the [[Criollo people|Insulares]], from whom, [[Filipino nationalism]] began. In 1863, the Spanish language was taught freely when a primary public school system was set up for the entire population. The Spanish-speaking [[Ilustrados]] (The Enlightened Ones), which included the Insulares, the Indios, the Mestizos, the Tornatrás, etc., were the educated elite who promoted and propagated nationalism and a modern Filipino consciousness. The Ilustrados and later writers formed the basis of [[Philippine literature in Spanish|Philippine Classical Literature]] which developed in the 19th century. José Rizal propagated Filipino consciousness and identity in Spanish. One material highly instrumental in developing nationalism was the novels entitled ''[[Noli Me Tangere (novel)|Noli Me Tangere]]'' and ''[[El Filibusterismo]]'' which exposed the abuses of the colonial government and clergy composed of Peninsulares. The novels' very own notoriety propelled its popularity even more among Filipinos. Reading it was forbidden because it exposed and parodied the Peninsulares in the Philippine Islands. ===Philippine–American War=== {{See also|Philippine–American War}} The revolutionary [[First Philippine Republic|Malolos Republic]] of 1899 designated the Spanish language for official use in its [[Malolos Constitution|constitution]], drawn up during the Constitutional Convention in [[Malolos]], [[Bulacan]].{{cite web | title =1899 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines Title XIV Article 93 | url=http://thecorpusjuris.com/laws/constitutions/item/1899-constitution.html | accessdate = 2012-01-01}} During this period, the nascent republic published a number of laws, acts, decrees, and other official issuances. These were published variously in the Spanish, English, and Tagalog languages, with the Spanish language predominating.{{Harvnb|Guevara|1972|p=[http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=philamer;cc=philamer;idno=aab1246.0001.001;size=S;frm=frameset;seq=12;page=root;view=image Contents]}} Spanish was also designated the official language of the [[Cantonal Republic of Negros]] of 1898 and the [[Republic of Zamboanga]] of 1899. Many Spanish-speaking Filipino families perished during the Philippine–American War. According to the historian James B. Goodno, author of the ''Philippines: Land of Broken Promises'' (New York, 1998), one-sixth of the total population of Filipinos or about 1.5 million died as a direct result of the war.{{cite book|last=Goodno|first=James B.|title=The Philippines: land of broken promises|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p3RxAAAAMAAJ|year=1991|publisher=Zed Books|isbn=978-0-86232-862-7|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=p3RxAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&dq=estimated+one–sixth 33]}}{{cite video |people=Filipinos and Americans during the Philippine–American War (producer: [https://www.youtube.com/user/fonsucu fonsucu]) |date=September 26, 2009 |title=Forgotten Filipinos/The Filipino genocide |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SfLJQYuSZSk|publisher=YouTube (youtube.com)|accessdate=July 30, 2010}}{{cite video |people= Filipinos and Americans during the Philippine–American War (producer: [https://www.youtube.com/user/fonsucu fonsucu])|date=September 26, 2009|title=El genocidio filipino/Los filipinos olvidados |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QqtXsZkWYkc|publisher=YouTube (youtube.com)|accessdate=July 30, 2010}} ===American colonial period=== {{See also|History of the Philippines (1898–1946)|American imperialism|History of the United States}} [[File:Jones Law poster Philippines 1916.jpeg|thumbnail| A poster advertising the [[Jones Law (Philippines)|Jones Law]] of 1916 in Spanish, ''The Glorious Jones Law'']] With the era of the Philippines as a Spanish colony with its people as Spanish citizens{{cite web|url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/rivera3.html|title=The Filipino State|first=Guillermo|last=Gómez Rivera|authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera|date=September 20, 2000|publisher=Buscoenlaces (buscoenlaces.es)|location=Spain|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rkiPPhc9?url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/rivera3.html|archivedate=August 5, 2010|accessdate=August 7, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} having just ended, a considerable amount of media, newspapers, radios, and government proceedings were still written and produced in Spanish. By law, the [[Taft Commission]] allowed their guests to use the language of their choice.{{Harvnb|Escalante|2007|p=88}} Ironically, the partial freedom of the press allowed by the American rulers served to further promote Spanish-language literacy among the masses. Even in the early 20th century, a [[hegemony]] of Spanish language was still in force. While the census of 1903 and of 1905 officially reported that the number of Spanish-speakers have never exceeded 10% of the total population during the final decade of the 19th century, it only considered Spanish speakers as their first and only language. It disregarded the Catholic [[Chinese Filipino]]s, many of whom spoke Spanish, and the creole-speaking communities. Furthermore, those who were academically instructed in the public school system also used Spanish as their second or third language. These together would have placed the numbers at more than 60% of the 9,000,000 Filipinos of that era as Spanish-speakers. In the Eighth Annual Report by the Director of Education, David P. Barrows, dated August 1, 1908, the following observations were made about the use and extension of the Spanish language in the Philippines:Eighth Annual Report, David P. Barrows, August 1, 1908, Bureau of Printing, 1957, Manila (P.94. Op.Cit.) {{quote| Of the adult population, including persons of mature years and social influence, the number speaking English is relatively small. This class speaks Spanish, and as it is the most prominent and important class of people in the Islands, Spanish continues to be the most important language spoken in political, journalistic and commercial circles.}} A 1916 report by [[Henry Jones Ford]] to President [[Woodrow Wilson]] said{{Cite web |url=http://emanila.com/pilipino/various/ggr_thomasites.htm |title=The Thomasites, Before and After|author=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |publisher=emanila.com |accessdate=2008-02-21 |ref=harv |postscript=}} {{quote| ...as I traveled through the Philippine Islands, using ordinary transportation and mixing with all classes of people under all conditions. Although based on the school statistics it is said that more Filipinos speak English than any other language, no one can be in agreement with this declaration if they base their assessment on what they hear... Spanish is everywhere the language of business and social intercourse...In order for anyone to obtain prompt service from anyone, Spanish turns out to be more useful than English...And outside of Manila it is almost indispensable. The Americans who travel around all the islands customarily use it. The use of Spanish as an official language has been extended to January 1, 1920. Its general use seems to be spreading. Natives acquiring it learn it as a living speech. Everywhere they hear it spoken by leading people of the community and their ears are trained to its pronunciation. On the other hand, they (the natives) are practically without phonic standards in acquiring English and the result is that they learn it as a book language rather than as a living speech. | Henry Jones Ford}} Although the English language had begun to be heavily promoted and used as the medium of education and government proceedings, the majority of literature produced by indigenous Filipinos during this period was in Spanish. Among the great Filipino literary writers of the period were Fernando M.a Guerrero, Rafael Palma, Cecilio Apóstol, [[Jesús Balmori]], Manuel Bernabé, Trinidad Pardo de Tavera and Teodoro M. Kalaw.Resil B. Mojares, [https://web.archive.org/web/20051125093709/http://www.ncca.gov.ph/culture%26arts/cularts/arts/literary/literary-philspain.htm Philippine Literature in Spanish] (archived from [http://www.ncca.gov.ph/culture&arts/cularts/arts/literary/literary-philspain.htm the original] on 2005-11-25). This explosion of Spanish language in [[Philippine literature in Spanish|Philippine literature]] occurred because the middle and upper class Filipinos were educated in Spanish and Spanish language as a subject was offered in public schools. In 1936, Philippine [[sound film]]s in Spanish began to be produced.{{cite web |url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/cine.html |title=Cine filipino en español |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |date=April 10, 2003 |publisher=Buscoenlaces ([http://www.buscoenlaces.es/ buscoenlaces.es]) |location=Spain |language=Spanish |trans-title=Philippine cinema in Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxo9Tkkj?url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/cine.html |archivedate=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Filipinos experienced a partial freedom of expression, since the American authorities weren't too receptive to Filipino writers and intellectuals during most of the colonial period. As a result, Spanish had become the most important language in the country. Until the Second World War, Spanish was the language of Manila. After the war, the English-speaking U.S. having won three wars [in 1898, against Spain ([[Spanish–American War]]); in 1913 (from [[Philippine–American War]] to [[Moro Rebellion]]) against the Filipino independence; in 1945 against Japan ([[Philippines Campaign (1944–45)|Philippines Campaign]])], the English language was imposed. ===Decline of the Spanish language=== {{See also|Language shift|Language death}} [[File:Manila Walled City Destruction May 1945.jpg|thumb|left|The destruction of [[Intramuros]] in May 1945 after the [[Battle of Manila (1945)|Battle of Manila]].]] The Spanish language flourished in the first two decades of the 20th century due to the partial freedom of the press and as an act of defiance against the new rulers. Spanish declined due to the imposition of English as the official language and medium of instruction in schools and universities.{{cite web |url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/libradav_eng.html |title=The Librada Avelino-Gilbert Newton Encounter (Manila, 1913) |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |date=February 11, 2001 |publisher=Buscoenlaces ([http://www.buscoenlaces.es/ buscoenlaces.es]) |location=Spain |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQ7TiDi?url=http://www.buscoenlaces.es/kaibigankastila/libradav_eng.html |archivedate=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The American administration increasingly forced editorials and newspapers to switch to English, leaving Spanish in a marginal position, so that [[Zobel de Ayala family|Enrique Zóbel de Ayala]] founded the [[Philippine Academy of the Spanish Language|Academia Filipina de la Lengua Española]] and the Premio Zóbel in 1924 to help maintain and develop the use of Spanish among the Filipino people. It did not help when some Filipino nationalists and nationalist [[historiography|historiographers]] during the American Colonial Period who took their liberal ideas from the writings of the 19th century [[Propaganda Movement|Filipino Propaganda]] which portrayed Spain and all things Spanish as negative or evil. Therefore, Spanish as a language was [[Demonization|demonized]] as a sad reminder of the past.{{cite web |url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20071204-104897/The_loss_of_Spanish |title=The loss of Spanish |first=[[Ambeth Ocampo|Ambeth]] |last=[[Ambeth Ocampo|Ocampo]] |date=December 4, 2007 |publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer (INQUIRER.net) |location=Makati City, Philippines |at=Opinion |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rVMuCBJ8?url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20071204-104897/The_loss_of_Spanish |archivedate=July 26, 2010 |accessdate=July 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} These ideas gradually inculcated into the minds of the young generation of Filipinos (during and after the American administration) who used those history textbooks at school that tended to generalize all Spaniards as villains due to lack of emphasis on [[Filipino people of Spanish ancestry]] who were also against the local Spanish government and clergy and also fought and died for the sake of freedom during the [[Philippine revolts against Spain#19th century|19th century revolts]], during the [[Philippine Revolution]], during the [[Philippine–American War]] and during World War II. {{cite web |url=http://www.inq7.net/opi/2002/mar/01/opi_arocampo-1.htm |title=The Spanish friar, beyond the propaganda |first=[[Ambeth Ocampo|Ambeth]]|last=[[Ambeth Ocampo|Ocampo]]|date=March 1, 2002|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer (INQUIRER.net, previously inq7.net) |location=Makati City, Philippines|at=Opinion|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020413133714/http://www.inq7.net/opi/2002/mar/01/opi_arocampo-1.htm |archivedate=April 13, 2002 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}}{{cite video |people=Filipino prisoners, Philippine–American War (producer: [https://www.youtube.com/user/fonsucu fonsucu]) |date=December 7, 2009 |title=Filipino Prisoners of War |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZXWk-zyM70Q |time=1:26 |publisher=YouTube (youtube.com)|accessdate=July 27, 2010|quote=Filipinos made prisoners by the USA army during the Philippine–American War}}{{cite video |people=Military, politicians, priests and writers who opposed the American colonial domination (producer: [https://www.youtube.com/user/fonsucu fonsucu]) |date=September 19, 2009 |title=Filipinos hispanos/Hispanic Filipinos |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CfvvGaxRGzA |publisher= YouTube (youtube.com)|accessdate=July 27, 2010 |quote=The invasion of the Philippines by the USA was fiercely resisted. Millions of Filipinos perished as a result of the American genocidal tactics.}} By the 1940s as children educated in English became adults, the Spanish language was starting to decline rapidly. Still, a very significant community of Filipino Spanish-speakers lived in the bigger cities, with a total population of roughly 300,000. However, with the destruction of [[Manila]] during the [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines|Japanese occupation]] in World War II, the heart of the Spanish language in the Philippines was dismantled.{{cite web |url=http://www.palhbooks.com/escoda.htm |title=Genocide in Manila |first=Miguel A. |last=Bernad |publisher=Philippine American Literary House (palhbooks.com) |location=California, USA |at=PALH Book Reviews |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rnry0cFo?url=http://www.palhbooks.com/escoda.htm |archivedate=August 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://archive.arabnews.com/?page=7§ion=0&article=91871&d=7&m=2&y=2007&pix=opinion.jpg&category=Opinion |title=The Warsaw of Asia: How Manila was Flattened in WWII |first=Manuel L. |last=Quezon III |authorlink=Manuel L. Quezon III |date=February 7, 2007 |publisher=Arab News Online (archive.arabnews.com) |location=Jeddah, Saudi Arabia |at=Opinion |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rnvPQM3p?url=http://archive.arabnews.com/?page=7§ion=0&article=91871&d=7&m=2&y=2007&pix=opinion.jpg&category=Opinion |archivedate=August 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.battlingbastardsbataan.com/som.htm |title=The Sack of Manila |publisher=The Battling Bastards of Bataan (battlingbastardsbataan.com) |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rnvf1Dhk?url=http://www.battlingbastardsbataan.com/som.htm |archivedate=August 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Many Spanish-speaking Filipino families perished during the massacre and bombing of the [[Cities of the Philippines|cities]] and [[Municipalities of the Philippines|municipalities]] between 1942 and 1945. By the end of the war, an estimated 1 million Filipinos lost their lives.{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2794.htm |title=Background Note: Philippines |publisher=U.S. Department of State (state.gov) |location=U.S.A. |at=American Period |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rntdHerp?url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2794.htm |archivedate=August 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Some of those Spanish-speakers who survived were forced to migrate in the later years. After the war, Spanish became increasingly marginalized at an official level. As English and American-influenced [[popular culture|pop culture]] increased, the use of Spanish in all aspects gradually declined. In 1962, when President [[Diosdado Macapagal]] decreed that the Philippines mark [[Independence Day (Philippines)|independence day]] on June 12 instead of July 4 which the country gained complete [[Republic Day (Philippines)|independence from the United States]], it revealed a tendency to paint Spain as the villain and the United States as saviour, or the more benevolent colonial power.{{cite web |url=http://www.oneworld.org/ips2/june98/05_37_013.html |title=PHILIPPINES: Torn Between Two Colonisers – Spain and America |first=Johanna |last=Son |date=June 9, 1998|location=Manila, Philippines |publisher=oneworld.org|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991009202835/http://www.oneworld.org/ips2/june98/05_37_013.html |archivedate=October 9, 1999 |accessdate=July 27, 2010}} The Spanish language and Hispanic culture was demonized again.{{cite web |url=http://lgpolar.com/page/read/119 |title=Educadores y sabios adredemente olvidados |first=Guillermo |last=Gómez Rivera |authorlink=Guillermo Gómez Rivera |date=March 2001 |trans-title=Forgotten Filipino Sages and Educators |publisher=La Guirnalda Polar (lgpolar.com) |location=Canada |at=Núm. 53 – Especial de Filipinas I |language=English, Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rn4RHtiX?url=http://lgpolar.com/page/read/119 |archivedate=August 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{failed verification|date=January 2014}} In 1973, Spanish briefly lost its status as an official language of the Philippines, was quickly redesignated as an official language, and finally did lose official status with the ratification of a subsequent constitution in 1987. ===21st-century developments=== {{See also|Language revitalization}} The 21st century has seen a revival of interest in the language, with the numbers of those studying it formally at college or taking private courses rising markedly in recent years.{{cite web | last =Rodríguez Ponga | first =Rafael | title = New Prospects for the Spanish Language in the Philippines (ARI) | url=http://www.realinstitutoelcano.org/wps/portal/rielcano_eng/Content?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/elcano/elcano_in/zonas_in/spanish+language+culture/ari27-2009 | accessdate = 2010-07-10}} Today, the [[Constitution of the Philippines|Philippine constitution]] provides that Spanish shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis.{{cite web |url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---ilo_aids/documents/legaldocument/wcms_126176.pdf |title=The 1987 Philippine Constitution (Article XIV-Education Section 7-Language)|author=Constitutional Commission of 1986 |date=October 15, 1986 | publisher=ilo.org |location=Philippines |page=28 Article XIV (Education) Section 7 (Language)|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ilo.org%2Fwcmsp5%2Fgroups%2Fpublic%2F---ed_protect%2F---protrav%2F---ilo_aids%2Fdocuments%2Flegaldocument%2Fwcms_126176.pdf&date=2010-07-16 |archivedate=July 16, 2010 |accessdate=July 16, 2010 |quote=Spanish and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis.}} A great portion of the history of the Philippines is written in Spanish and, up until recently, many [[land title]]s, contracts, newspapers and [[Literature of the Philippines|literature]] were still written in Spanish.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927091905/http://www.pnm.my/motw/philippines/3national_archives.htm The National Archives] (archived from [http://www.pnm.my/motw/philippines/3national_archives.htm the original] on 2007-09-27), Houses the Spanish Collection, which consists of around 13 million manuscripts from the Spanish colonial period. Today, Spanish is being somewhat revived in the Philippines by groups rallying to make it a compulsory subject in school.{{cite web|title=Spanish is once again a compulsory subject in the Philippines|url=http://www.schoolsandcourses.com/noticias_ver.asp?idNoticia=238|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rE2xF3Ga?url=http://www.schoolsandcourses.com/noticias_ver.asp?idNoticia=238|archivedate=July 14, 2010|accessdate=July 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Republic Act No. 9187 was approved on February 5, 2003 and signed by President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]], declaring June 30 of every year as [[Philippine–Spanish Friendship Day]] to commemorate the cultural and historical ties, friendship and cooperation between the Philippines and Spain.{{cite web |url=http://www.congress.gov.ph/download/ra_12/RA09187.pdf |title=Republic Act No. 9187: An Act declaring June 30 of the year as Philippine–Spanish Friendship Day, appropriating funds therefor and for other purposes |author=Congress of the Philippines |year=2003|location=Metro Manila, Philippines|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.congress.gov.ph%2Fdownload%2Fra_12%2FRA09187.pdf&date=2010-07-15 |archivedate=July 15, 2010 |accessdate=July 16, 2010}} On July 3, 2006, the [[Union of Local Authorities of the Philippines]] created Resolution No. 2006-028 urging the national government to support and promote the teaching of the Spanish language in all public and private universities and colleges in the Philippines.{{cite web |url=http://www.ulap.gov.ph/reso2006-28.html |title=Resolution No. 2006-028: Urging the national government to support and promote the teaching of the Spanish language in all public and private universities and colleges in the Philippines|author=Union of Local Authorities of the Philippines (ULAP)|date=July 3, 2006|publisher= ulap.gov.ph |location=Manila, Philippines |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902192237/http://www.ulap.gov.ph/reso2006-28.html |archivedate=September 2, 2007 |accessdate=July 16, 2010}} On December 17, 2007, the [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Department of Education]] issued Memorandum No. 490, s. 2007 encouraging secondary schools to offer basic and advanced Spanish in the 3rd and 4th year levels respectively, as an elective.{{cite web | last =Labrador | first =Vilma | title =DepEd Memorandum No. 490, s. 2007 – The Spanish Language as an Elective in High School | url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/cpanel/uploads/issuanceImg/DM%20No.%20490,%20s.%202007.pdf | archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/5rE36eheu?url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/cpanel/uploads/issuanceImg/DM%20No.%20490%2C%20s.%202007.pdf | archivedate =July 14, 2010 | accessdate =July 19, 2010 | deadurl =yes | df = }} {{as of|2008}}, there was a growing demand for Spanish-speaking agents in the call center industry as well as in the business process outsourcing in the Philippines for the Spanish and American market. Around 7,000 students were enrolled in the Spanish language classes of the Instituto Cervantes de Manila for the school year 2007–2008.{{cite web | last =Uy | first =Veronica | title =Demand for Spanish speakers growing | date=November 19, 2008|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer (INQUIRER.net) |location=Makati City, Philippines |url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/news/breakingnews/view/20081119-173154/Demand-for-Spanish-speakers-growing|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fglobalnation.inquirer.net%2Fnews%2Fbreakingnews%2Fview%2F20081119-173154%2FDemand-for-Spanish-speakers-growing&date=2010-07-14 |archivedate=July 14, 2010| accessdate = July 19, 2010}} On December 11, 2008, the Department of Education issued Memorandum No. 560, s. 2008 that shall implement the Special Program in Foreign Language on a pilot basis starting school year 2009–2010. The program shall initially offer Spanish as a foreign language in one school per region, at two classes of 35 students each, per school.{{cite web|last=Sangil Jr.|first=Teodosio|title=DepEd Memorandum No. 560, s. 2008 – Special Program in Foreign Language|url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/cpanel/uploads/issuanceImg/DM%20No.%20560,%20s.%202008.pdf|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rE3oR1N1?url=http://www.deped.gov.ph/cpanel/uploads/issuanceImg/DM%20No.%20560%2C%20s.%202008.pdf|archivedate=July 14, 2010|accessdate=July 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} As of 2009, the Spanish government has offered to fund a project and even offered scholarship grants to Spain for public school teachers and students who would like to study Spanish or take up a master's degree in four top universities in Spain. The Spanish government has been funding the ongoing pilot teacher training program about the Spanish language, involving two months of face-to-face classes and a 10-month on-line component.{{cite web | last =Tubeza | first =Philip | title =Scholarships for teachers to learn Spanish | url =http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090426-201554/Scholarships-for-teachers-to-learn-Spanish | archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/5rE42UnW8?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090426-201554/Scholarships-for-teachers-to-learn-Spanish | archivedate =July 14, 2010 | accessdate =July 19, 2010 | deadurl =yes | df = }} ''Clásicos Hispanofilipinos'' is a project of Instituto Cervantes de Manila which aims to promote Filipino heritage and preserve and reintroduce the works of great Fil-Hispanic authors of the early 20th century to the new generation of Filipino [[Hispanophone]]s. The Spanish novel of [[Jesús Balmori]] entitled ''Los Pájaros de Fuego'' (''Birds of Fire'') which was mostly written during the Japanese occupation was published by the Instituto June 28, 2010.{{cite web | publisher=The Philippine Star | title =Instituto Cervantes publishes Jesús Balmori's 'Los Pajáros de Fuego' | url =http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=586110&publicationSubCategoryId=79 | archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/5rE4C5dIG?url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=586110&publicationSubCategoryId=79 | archivedate =July 14, 2010 | accessdate =July 19, 2010 | deadurl =yes | df = }} King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] commented in 2007 that, "In fact, some of the beautiful pages of Spanish literature were written in the Philippines".{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20071205-104920/Spain%92s_king_hails_Arroyo%2C_RP_democracy |title=Spain’s king hails Arroyo, RP democracy |first=Michael Lim |last=Ubac |date=December 5, 2007 |publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer (INQUIRER.net) |location=Makati City, Philippines |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rFKzmbkV?url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20071205-104920/Spain%92s_king_hails_Arroyo%2C_RP_democracy |archivedate=July 15, 2010 |accessdate=July 16, 2010 |quote=In fact, some of the beautiful pages of Spanish literature were written in the Philippines |deadurl=yes |df= }} During her visit to the Philippines in July 2012, [[Queen Sofía of Spain|Sofia of Spain]] expressed her support for the Spanish language to be revived in Philippine schools.{{cite web |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=824156 |title=Queen Sofia wants Spanish back in Philippine public schools |date=July 5, 2012 |publisher=The Philippine Star (philstar.com)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/264032/news/nation/pnoy-and-spains-queen-sofia-welcome-return-of-spanish-language-in-phl-schools |title=PNoy (President Benigno Aquino III) and Spain’s Queen Sofia welcome return of Spanish language in Philippine schools |first=Amita O. |last=Legaspi |date=July 3, 2012 |publisher=GMA News}} On September 11, 2012, saying that there were 318 Spanish-trained basic education teachers in the Philippines, Philippine secretary of the Department of Education [[Armin Luistro]] announced an agreement with the [[Chile|Chilean]] government to train Filipino school teachers in Spanish. In exchange, the Philippines would help train Chilean teachers in English.{{Cite web |url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/49782/deped-mulls-spanish-for-students|title=DepEd mulls Spanish for students|last=Mangunay |first=Kristine |accessdate=13 September 2012}} ==Current status== Since the independence of the Philippines from Spain (1898), the dialect has lost most of its speakers and it might be now close to disappearing.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Spanish was the language of government, education and trade throughout the three centuries (333 years) of the Philippines being part of the [[Spanish Empire]] and continued to serve as a [[lingua franca]] until the first half of the 20th century. In the last decades its use has declined.{{Cite web|url=http://www.realinstitutoelcano.org/wps/portal/rielcano/contenido?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/elcano/elcano_es/zonas_es/asia-pacifico/ari27-2009|title=Nuevas perspectivas para la lengua española en Filipinas (ARI)|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} New developments in the Philippines are slowly reversing this trend. In December 2007, former [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] signed a directive in [[Spain]] that require the teaching and learning of the Spanish language in the Philippine school system starting in 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mecd.gob.es/filipinas/en_PH/estudiar/en-filipinas|title=Spanish in Philippine Public High School|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} The presidential decision had immediate results. The Under-Secretary of the [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Department of Education]], Vilma L. Labrador, circulated a Memorandum (17/XII/2007), on the ''"Restoration of the Spanish language in Philippine Education"''. In it, the Department mandates secondary schools to offer basic and advanced Spanish. There has been a resurgence of learning Spanish among Filipinos, for various reasons. Interest in the language and recuperation of it as part of their history, namely their written, cultural history, interest in their connection to the Spanish-speaking world, among others. Due to the huge demand for Spanish speakers among [[business process outsourcing]] companies in the Philippines, Filipinos are flocking to [[Instituto Cervantes]] and other language centers in order to learn Spanish.{{Cite web|url=http://yaleglobal.yale.edu/content/hola-asian-call-centers-lure-back-spanish|title=Hola! Asian Call Centers Lure Back Spanish|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=YaleGlobal - Yale University|access-date=}} {{clarify span|text=For most of the less educated population, Spanish is acquired through [[Hispanic music]], or for some, especially children, by watching [[Dora the Explorer]] in [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]]. For the educated population, Spanish is further enriched through watching [[Telenovela]]s from the internet or watching the cable channel of [[Televisión Española]].{{cite web|last=Ocampo|first=Ambeth|title=Spanish on comeback trail in Philippines|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20071206-105314/Spanish_on_comeback_trail_in_Philippines|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rE4Vg911?url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20071206-105314/Spanish_on_comeback_trail_in_Philippines|archivedate=July 14, 2010|accessdate=July 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} That results in the lack of general characteristics that describe its phonological system.|explain=Does this deal with native or 2nd language speakers?|date=October 2016}} {{as of|2012}}, of the younger generation of [[Hispanophone|Filipino Hispanophones]] are following the [[Spanish orthography|Spanish orthographic]] convention of typing letters with [[diacritic|diacritic marks]] ([[acute accent]]s and [[Diaeresis (diacritic)|diaeresis]]) as well as the [[inverted question and exclamation marks]] and the rest of the special characters and symbols found in [[Spanish orthography]] on their US standard layout computer keyboards by using the [[AltGr key]], [[Modifier key]], [[Code page 437]], [[Code page 850]], [[Microsoft Windows]] [[Alt Key]] [[Alt code|Numeric Codes]] for [[Character (symbol)|character]] shortcuts, or the [[US-International]] keyboard layout.{{cn|date=August 2017}} ===Media=== Spanish-language media was present in the 2000s with one Spanish newspaper, ''[[E-Dyario]]'', the first Spanish digital newspaper published in the Philippines, and ''[[Filipinas, Ahora Mismo]]'' was a nationally syndicated, 60-minute, cultural radio magazine program in the Philippines broadcast daily in Spanish for two years in the 2000s. Since the emergence of [[social media]], Spanish speaking Filipinos have tended to use these more modern forms to continue publishing in Spanish language. ==Influence on the languages of the Philippines== {{See also|Old Spanish language|Linguistic history of Spanish}} There are approximately 4,000 Spanish words in Tagalog (between 20% and 33% of Tagalog words), and around 6,000 Spanish words in Visayan and other Philippine languages. The Spanish counting system, calendar, time, etc. are still in use with slight modifications. Archaic Spanish words have been preserved in Tagalog and the other vernaculars, such as {{wiktspa|pera}} (''coins''), {{wiktspa|sabón}} [{{wiktspa|jabón}}) at the beginning of Spanish rule, the ''j'' used to be pronounced {{IPA|[ʃ]}}, the [[voiceless postalveolar fricative]] or the "sh" sound; (''soap'')], {{wiktspa|relos}} [({{wiktspa|reloj}}) with the ''j'' sound; (''watch'')], {{wiktspa|kwarta}} ({{wiktspa|cuarta}}; ''money''), etc.{{cite web | title =El español en Filipinas | url =http://spanish-differences.com/Spanish/Philippines-Spanish.php | archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/5rDzFAFMZ?url=http://spanish-differences.com/Spanish/Philippines-Spanish.php | archivedate =July 14, 2010 | accessdate =July 19, 2010 | deadurl =yes | df = }} The Spaniards and the language are referred to as either ''Kastila'' or ''Katsila'' (mostly [[Visayan languages]]) after {{wiktspa|Castilla}} (''[[Castile (historical region)|Castile]]''), the original Spanish Kingdom under which Spain was unified in 1492, which later became a Spanish region. [[Chavacano]] (also called Zamboangueño), is a Spanish-based creole language spoken mainly in the southern province of Zamboanga and, to a much lesser extent, in the province of Cavite in the northern region of [[Luzon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.personal.psu.edu/faculty/j/m/jml34/chabacano.pdf |title=Chabacano, Spanish and the Philippine Linguistic Identity |last=Lipski |first=John M. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rE518HM7?url=http://www.personal.psu.edu/faculty/j/m/jml34/chabacano.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2010 |accessdate=July 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Chavacano became the main language in the [[Zamboanga City]] and some parts of [[Zamboanga Peninsula]], as a result of the migration into the area of a large number of workers, who came from different linguistic regions to build military and other Spanish establishments. ===Morphosemantic changes=== {{See also|Spanish dialects and varieties}} While many Spanish words have entered Tagalog, Cebuano, Waray-Waray, and other Philippine languages, many of the words have seen a shift in meaning and even construction from the original Spanish. That has resulted in [[false friends]], similar words in both languages but with a different meaning. A sample is shown below: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Word ! Language ! Meaning in the Philippines ! Original Spanish word !
